Articles.Content:
Coming soon.

(Suggestions on rocket power, ISP etc would be helpful for these rockets above)
...You should make your own models.. If We wanted resized parts, we could do that ourselves.. Sorry to burst your bubble

...You should make your own models.. If We wanted resized parts, we could do that ourselves.. Sorry to burst your bubble

Constructive criticism tends to be better recieved when you say it nicely

Looking back on that comment, I sound like a jar of dirt. My Apologies.

(For the record, It DID have reason to it,)

it's just stock engines....with elongated nozzles?

what? no original content?

it's just stock engines....with elongated nozzles?

what? no original content?

Well, we all need to start somewhere.

Anyway, It is nice to see a stock-alike modder. I Personally like the design of the elongated nossels- maybe if you combine it with the shape of the radioisotope generators, you could turn it into a smaller nuke engine.

To be honest, I've never thought about using model nodes this way. I take it you're nesting two models, one of which is stretched?

On balance, I think you should increase the thrust and Isp, if for nothing else but to compensate for their unwieldiness. Secondly, how will you deal with the jettison modules / fairings on the relevant engines?

Easy, blender .mu opener my friend

The entire model is not stretched but the nozzles.

About people saying it is not original then i can't model that well.

(out of scene is a dual engine made from smallen LV-30 engines)

If you have trouble with Blender for modeling, you could do what I do. I model over in sketchup (prepares for rage war) and then imports to Blender to do the UV unwrap, then send it to my mod team to get it textured (which I lack the skills and software to do, not very skilled with GIMP). Then I get it back, do the Unity work and write a .cfg for it. Working part! If you want help with trying such method, feel free to shoot me a PM.

Interesting although im no good with UV unwrapping

Anyway thanks for the tip (i also use sketchup)
